intro: Platystele hypsitera, commonly known as the highland ghost plant, is a rare and enigmatic member of the Bromeliaceae family. It is an epiphytic plant, meaning it grows on the surfaces of other plants without deriving nutrients from them. The plant is characterized by its slender, leafless stems and small, inconspicuous flowers that are often hidden within its dense foliage. Native to the cloud forests of Central and South America, it thrives in humid, shaded environments. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered endangered and is of great interest to botanists and conservationists.
